sen.j: 祭壇（さいだん）は、神や精霊、死などに生贄や供物を捧げる為の壇。
sen.e: An altar is a structure to offer sacrifices and oblations to gods, spirits, and death.
An altar is a structure for making sacrifices and offerings to gods, spirits, and death.

sen.j: 祭壇は各宗教によって異なり、大小さまざまであるが、最も大きなものは中国で天を祭った祭壇（天壇）である。
sen.e: The style of altars varies among religions and it varies in size as well, and the biggest one is the Temple of Heaven, the altar made to enshrine the heaven in China.
The style and size of altars varies from religion to religion, with the biggest one being the Temple of Heaven in China, made to enshrine Heaven.

sen.j: 祭壇の形態は多様で、台や板状の自然石を用いたもの（石壇）、土を盛り上げて作ったもの（土壇）、石を積み上げて作ったもの（石積壇）、地面に獣の皮やコモを敷いたものなどがある。
sen.e: There are various types of altars such as an altar made of a stand or board shaped natural stone (a stone altar), an altar made by piling up earth (a soil altar), an altar made by laying stones (a stonework altar), and an altar set up by spreading animal skins or straw mats on the ground.

sen.j: はじめは自然物を使用・あるいは加工した形態のものが次第に神殿の建設など複雑な構造を持つものに変化していった。
sen.e: The early altars were made up by using natural objects or people just arranged natural objects, and then altars became more structurally complicated, such as construction of shrines.

sen.j: 構造の複雑化に伴い、使用する材料も多様化し大理石、金属などを用いたものや入念な装飾をもつものが現れるようになった。
sen.e: As their structure became more complicated, various ranges of materials became popular and people started to use marble or metal, or they sometimes applied elaborate decorations to altars.

sen.j: 神道においては正月などの祭事に臨時に設置する歳棚などが起源とされ、常設されるようになったのは中世以降のことである。
sen.e: It is said that the origin of Shinto altars was toshidana, a shelf set up specially for rituals including the New Year, and they became a permanent structure in the Middle Ages or later.

sen.j: 神像を祭る場合は、神像を中心として屋根で覆ったり、厨子や神輿を用いたりして祠を作る形態が一般的。
sen.e: When enshrining an image of a deity, people usually cover the altar with a roof centering on the image and build a hokora (a small shrine) with a zushi (a small sacred cabinet with a double-leaf door) or a mikoshi (a portable shrine).

sen.j: 神を祭る為に石を巡らしたり、積んだりして祭る場所としたもの（磐境）、神佑地に常盤木を立て神座としたもの（神籬）がある。
sen.e: The Shinto altars are divided into two types: one is called iwasaka, a place to enshrine a deity built up by enclosing with or laying stones and the other is called himorogi, a place to enshrine an object of worship built up by planting evergreen trees in a sanctuary.

sen.e: In addition, a soreisha (a small shrine dedicated to family ancestral spirits) is prepared separately from a kamidama (a household Shinto altar) when people enshrine the deceased.

sen.j: キリスト教では聖堂内においてミサの執行される台を一般に祭壇と呼称する。
sen.e: In Christianity, a platform at where a mass is held in a church is commonly referred to as an altar.

sen.j: イエス・キリストの事跡、「最後の晩餐」の食卓を模ったものとして古くから存在していた。
sen.e: Altars have represented the vestige of Jesus Christ or the dining table of 'The Last Supper' since ancient times.

sen.e: There are also some gorgeous altars which have gold and silver relief on the side as well as the front, and the altar at the Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio in Milan is one of such altars.

sen.e: The altars at inner sanctums in the Orthodox Church's churches are called Holy Table (the Orthodox Church).

sen.e: The altar types used in Buddhism include a permanent altar called shumidan which is set up to enshrine an image of Buddha, a household altar referred to as butsudan, a temporary altar for funerals and religious ceremonies, an altar called chuindan which is placed until the Buddhist memorial service after 49 days of a person's death, and an altar called shoryudana (or bondana) which is provided for the Bon festival (the festival of the dead).
